title: How to Repair Your Dishwasher’s Door Latch

steps.headline: Look around the edge of the inner door panel to find eleven screws.
steps.description: Use your Torx driver to remove these. After you lift up the inner panel, the door latch mechanism should be exposed. You are going to need to separate the electrical connections from the switch, so use a screwdriver to pry them off. Be gentle to avoid damaging these components.

steps.headline: Use a screwdriver to latch the small cam of the handle by pressing on it.
Take the handle off.
steps.description: With a flat screwdriver, pry off one end while you simultaneously lift the handle.

steps.headline: Lift one side of the handle and push it toward the other end as you pry it away from the door latch gently.
steps.description: Two pivot points should be free at this point. Slide the handle forward, then lift the handle away from the dishwasher.

steps.headline: Transfer the dishwasher handle to the new latch without any problems.
steps.description: All you'll need to do is slide both of the two inner pivot points mentioned earlier. Fortunately, both of these points have been tapered, which makes the reattachment process a breeze.

steps.headline: Take hold of the handle and pull it up until you can see that it has locked into place completely.
steps.description: At this point, you can simply turn the latch in place so that it's facing down and then snap it at one of its sides with the use of the tapered pivot. This should allow the other side to slide in without any trouble. Make sure to note that this latch will remain in its locked position until you eventually re-install it in the dishwasher.

steps.headline: Use the wire harnesses to stabilize the dishwasher's electrical wires.
steps.description: You can easily find these by lifting up the door. There is plenty inside the dishwasher to push against the wires, so make sure they're not touching anything.

steps.headline: Perform a final check of the latch before you start putting the screws back on the inner panel.
steps.description: Put it in place and set the handle through the slot on the door. Put all eleven screws back on, then open the door to make sure that handle is working as it should. Turning on the dishwasher is the final test because a disconnected latch will actually prevent the dishwasher from starting at all. As long as both of your tests work out, you've successfully fixed your dishwasher's door latch.

text: Look around the edge of the inner door panel to find eleven screws. Use your Torx driver to remove these. After you lift up the inner panel, the door latch mechanism should be exposed. You are going to need to separate the electrical connections from the switch, so use a screwdriver to pry them off. Be gentle to avoid damaging these components. Use a screwdriver to latch the small cam of the handle by pressing on it.  Take the handle off. With a flat screwdriver, pry off one end while you simultaneously lift the handle. Lift one side of the handle and push it toward the other end as you pry it away from the door latch gently. Two pivot points should be free at this point. Slide the handle forward, then lift the handle away from the dishwasher. Transfer the dishwasher handle to the new latch without any problems. All you'll need to do is slide both of the two inner pivot points mentioned earlier. Fortunately, both of these points have been tapered, which makes the reattachment process a breeze. Take hold of the handle and pull it up until you can see that it has locked into place completely. At this point, you can simply turn the latch in place so that it's facing down and then snap it at one of its sides with the use of the tapered pivot. This should allow the other side to slide in without any trouble. Make sure to note that this latch will remain in its locked position until you eventually re-install it in the dishwasher. Use the wire harnesses to stabilize the dishwasher's electrical wires. You can easily find these by lifting up the door. There is plenty inside the dishwasher to push against the wires, so make sure they're not touching anything. Perform a final check of the latch before you start putting the screws back on the inner panel. Put it in place and set the handle through the slot on the door. Put all eleven screws back on, then open the door to make sure that handle is working as it should. Turning on the dishwasher is the final test because a disconnected latch will actually prevent the dishwasher from starting at all. As long as both of your tests work out, you've successfully fixed your dishwasher's door latch.
